sub_title: Associate Professor at the Eindhoven University of Technology
summary:
It is my ambition to contribute to the development of renewable energy via solving fundamental physical problems.  My scientific interests are in heat and mass transport in porous media in connection to phase transitions.  I am guiding a team of PhD students an postdocs that investigates the physical-chemistry of materials for heat storage with the goal to improve them. A class of materials that have my interest are the so-called TCM's (Thermo-Chemical Materials), materials that can store heat via reversible reactions with for example water. I focus on four different aspects:

1) Manipulating TCM's to make a better fit between use conditions and phase behavior.
2) Improve kinetics of charging/discharging of TCM's in order to increase power output.
3) Boost the thermal conductivity of TCM's to improve the power output.
4) Mechanical stabilization of TCM particles to have reliable cyclic performance.

Next to the topic of heat storage, I have worked for more than 10 years on water/ion migration through polymer films and coatings.

treasury_media.title: Lecture @ AMOLF Amsterdam - March 13 2023
treasury_media.description: At AMOLF I discussed the progress we made on understanding and manipulating the hydration reactions of salt hydrates, which is important for improving the power output of salt hydrate based heat battery.

awards.title: Collaborative University Competition: NoVOC
awards.description:
A team  of students from the Eindhoven University of Technology, supervised by Alex van Herk and Henk Huinink, has won the Collaborative University Competition organized by HCG (Harryson Consulting Group) and AkzoNobel. The challenge was to come up with a coating without "volatile organic compounds" (VOCs) and good film properties. Reduction of VOCs in paints/coatings is important from environmental point of view.

HCG: http://iknow-who.com/

projects.title: CREATE
projects.description: In a consortium of several European compagnies and knowledges institutes, a demonstration unit for compact seasonal heat storage will be developed. At the TU/e we are responsible for the development of stable materials serving as storage medium. This task is done in collaboration with TNO, Dow, Tessenderlo, Caldic and d'Appolonia.

projects.title: TSoF (= True Solvent Free Coatings)
projects.description: Solvent free coatings (no organic solvents) are the holy grail for the coating industry. The film formation of waterborne (and solvent free) coatings will be studied with NMR imaging at the Eindhoven University of Technology. At the Wageningen University DWS (diffusive wave scattering) will be used to monitor the micro rheology during film formation. With hybrid LB-MD models the film formation process will be modeled at the Eindhoven University of Technology. The projects runs in collaboration with DSM CoatingResins, Oce, AkzoNobel, Drywood and SHR.

projects.title: BioWoPro (Biofilms for Wood Protection)
projects.description: Aureobasidium Pullulans is a fungi that seems to protect wood against rot. Researchers of TNO have given a proof of principle of the protective action of biofilms of this fungal specie. In the project BioWoPro (Biofilms for Wood Protection) mycologists of the CBS and physicists of the Eindhoven University of Technology work together to characterize the growth of the biofilm in relation to physical conditions of the environment.

projects.title: Towards Green Inks - TGInk
projects.description: Water based inks seem to have the future in inkjet printing applications. Basically these inks consists of pigment and polymeric particles dispersed in water. In order to have good print quality the pigment en polymer particles should stay at the surface of the paper after the ink droplet has hit the paper surface. The problem is that paper tends to suck the ink by capillary forces and along with the fluid the particles migrate into the paper. In a joined project of the Eindhoven University of Technology, M2i and Oce the migration of particles in the paper fabric is studied. The goal is to find the key parameters determining the particle penetration and thereby the handles to improve waterbased inks.

projects.title: Water transport through coatings on wood
projects.description: An important reason to apply coatings on wood is to protect wood against water. In order to use waterborne coatings for woodcare the main factors determining transport through these coatings have to be understood. Waterborne coatings are intrinsically more sensitive to water. Further, the influence of wood on the coating structure and permeability have to be understood. In this project the migration of water through waterborne coatings on wood will be studied with NMR imaging tools. NMR imaging is very suitable tool for visualizing water distributions in the wood and the coating. Further, NMR also gives information about the state of water (bound or free) and plasticization effects (polymer-water interactions).

projects.title: Fungal growth on porous media under transient humidity
projects.description: Fungal growth in the indoor environment is unwanted due to its impact on the indoor air quality. In many case biological growths takes place on materials that are porous in nature. Due to porosity of the materials the interplay between the dynamics of growth and water is an important factor. We study this process both from a physical and biological viewpoint. Work is performed together with TNO, the Center for Fungal Biodiversity (CBS-KNAW) and the University of Utrecht. The projects on this topic are funded by TNO and STW (foundation for applied research).

projects.title: Water transport through multilayer coatings
projects.description: Polymeric coatings are applied for several reasons on substrates: appearance, protection, etc. Coatings should exihibit good barrier properties. Together with AkzoNobel and TNO I am working on imaging and modeling water transport through these coatings.

projects.title: Water and ion transport through nylon-6 films
projects.description: Within the framework of the MuST program (an STW program on Multiscale research) we are studying water and ion migration in thin nylon-6 films. Within NMR imaging we probe the time evolution of the water distribution inside the films. NMR relaxometry is used to elucidate the state of water and the plasticization of the nylon-6.

profile_positions.description:
As member of the MT of the Eindhoven Institute for Renewable Energy Systems (EIRES), I am responsible for the focus area Systems for Sustainable Energy.

https://www.tue.nl/en/research/institutes/eindhoven-institute-for-renewable-energy-systems/
profile_positions.title: Principal Scientist - EIRES / Systems for Sustainable Heat

profile_positions.description:
My ambition is to contribute via fundamental science to development of technology facilitating the use of renewable energy. With my fellow staff members we are refocussing our research on heat storage materials.

At the moment I am a staff member of the group Transport in Permeable Media, a research group within the Department of Applied Physics of the TU/e. I am involved in modelling, supervising PhD students, teaching of BSc and MSc courses and acquisition of research projects.

I am always interested in complex multidisciplinary research projects. At the moment my projects cover topics  related to transport and phase change processes in polymeric and porous materials.My new projects have a focus on material science for compact and long term heat storage.
profile_positions.title: Associate Professor
